Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: This class is not something you can get through completely by memorizing the steps of how to do certain problems. You will learn how to learn the concepts in order to answer conceptual exam questions that don't ask you to solve a problem.
Good class for transitioning from high school calculus into college math.
Really loved the class, it really taught me how to engage with mathematics.
A lot of useful techniques for vector calculus and engineering
Multivariable calculus
This course forced me to think critically about not just math but also physics. This class moved at a pace that I was not used to so I had to force myself to work even harder to keep up.
I learned both the theorems of multivariable calculus and their applications in problem-solving.
I leaned basic operations and concepts in multi variable calculus.

ENAS 151 is a standard multivariable calculus class, where you just go through the chapters of the text. You learn about functions of three variables, planar approximations, vector calculus (including Green's, Gauss's, and Stoke's theorems), and everything else in a multivariable calc class. If you're deciding between MATH 120 and ENAS 151, I would say to think if you want to take linear algebra: if yes, I would suggest MATH 120; but if you do not plan to take linear algebra, then ENAS 151 is a great alternative. The final is not cumulative, but the exams are very difficult. The lectures are deceiving with Vidvuds Ozolins: they're easy, but the exams are unnecessarily difficult. The lowest 3 pset grades are dropped, and the lowest quarter of the pre-lecture quizzes are dropped, not to mention your lowest to highest midterm scores receive 15%, 20%, and 25% weighting, respectively. However, THERE IS NO CURVE. Do not expect a curve in this class: only if the entire class failed an exam would Ozolins change the score, and he only added 10 points.
I believe I have a gained a deep conceptual understanding of multivariable calculus and have a general understanding of how topics can be applied to engineering.

ENAS 151 is a rigorous multivariable course. I feel like I have more knowledge of working in 3d, major theorems, etc. than students who took Math 120, and more applied knowledge than students who took Math 230.
Experience was gained with visualizing 3D surfaces, partial derivatives, Lagrange multipliers, gauss' theorem, stoke's theorem, and green's theorem.

Gives you the basic introduction to Multivariable Calculus

Very similar to Math 120, just a little bit more applied.
I learnt multivariable calculus.
I learned how to perform calculations using Multivariable Calculus and how to use the Math knowledge to solve real-world problems.
How to suffer through unnecessarily difficult exams!
Multivarible calculus, including Green, Stokes, and Gauss. Also generally useful problem solving techniques for physics and math problems.
I learned some concepts of Multi-variable Calculus;however, it was difficult to learn as lectures were confusing and much of the class was dependent on self-teaching from the textbook.
Visualizing surfaces, double and triple integrals, line and surface integrals. Vector fields and functions

What we learned was pretty much outlined in the syllabus, but after talking to some friends who took ENAS 151 in the past, I think we might've delved deeper into the less often used applications of the main ideas.  It was definitely a ton of content, but I think it'll set me up well for future math classes.
A decent amount, but I learned them on my own time by reading the textbook. I really like the professor as a person, but not as a teacher.

I learned about multiple integrals and multiple derivatives and how to utilize them in practical ways (work, flux, etc.) Additionally, I was able to work on my problem solving ability and get better at it with the problems that the instructor posed to us.
Critical thinking and mathematical reasoning.
I learned multivariable calculus on a more applied level and was able to better understand the links between the concepts and physics interpretation.
Learning 3D thinking, got into the habit of working on weekly psets. conceptualizing  3D shapes. learned cool things about vector calculus.

I feel like I have a pretty good grasp on multivariable calculus after this class. I did not have any prior experience with this high of a level of a math class. I think after this course I have a fairly good grasp on the concepts that we learned throughout the course (vector calculus, double and triple integrals, flux and surface integrals, and the other concepts that are taught in this course). It was also my first college math class, so it introduced psets and a college level work load. It got me used to how to learn from a lecture class and also how to develop my skills by myself outside of the class.
I developed the ability to manage my time for large work loads effectively by taking this course. You
You learn the basic skills of multivariable calculus but little on how to apply them in class so when it comes to assessments students do not know which skills to apply to each problem.
I learned to have a better understanding of a 3 dimension world. Also, I further developed my skills to derive and integrate in different dimensions.
I learned how to do more math!
I learned the math, and I think I learned it well. Pretty much all there is to it.
Lectures were good. Prof. Ozolins supplemented the powerpoints with example problems that really helped illustrate the math.
I did not really like the inverted class setting, I really learned more and better when the prof lectured from the board.

The course changed format a couple of times throughout the semester, which was a little strange for the students to experience. However, overall I learned a lot of useful concepts that I will probably use later on in other classes.

The material in this course is challenging. The problem sets are very long and difficult. The tests are unnecessarily hard. The class had very limited resources to help students. There are no peer tutors and the TAs are not very helpful. The psets are very long. Meet during reading period and had pset due on the friday after reading period.

The strengths were the professor's personality. Weaknesses: the tests were WAY more difficult than what we did in class so I always felt unready. Also, it was extremely annoying that over half the class had already taken multivariable calc so not only did they completely kill the curve on every exam, but it also made it seem as though who did poorly in the class did not know what was going on. When in reality, people were only doing so well because they had seen the material before.

I liked that there was reading to do before each class, but having a short quiz on the material before we learned it in class was frustrating for the harder topics. It was great to have 3 equally weighted exams because there was less pressure, and psets counted for more of the grade than they do in 120, which really puts an emphasis on effort and practice. We moved pretty quickly at the end, so perhaps the first few topics could be condensed. I think that this class could be more structured because it often felt like we were just deciding how the class would be run as we went along.

Strenghts: This class is built to be for engineering students, so most of the problems were applicable to real life situations. 

Weaknesses: This class was more difficult than it had to be. More than half of the class had already taken multi variable calculus in high school and those who did not were easily left behind.

The strengths of this course include learning multivariable calculus, but the weaknesses overcome the strengths significantly. This class is a lecture course, and although I learned some topics in lecture, the lectures did not sufficiently prepare me for the exams. I had already taken multivariable calculus before (with passing grades), but this class was still difficult for me. The professor (Vidvuds Ozolins) was helpful when you went to office hours, but he seemed too arrogant on his exams: specifically, he would laugh or be humble when he made his tests to hard. He though it was a compliment that we felt miserable over the difficulty of the tests. I think if the test were less hard or if the lectures and the psets prepared us more for the exams, the class would be better (although you would still have to do a lot of work: one pset was 30 questions and took hours).
The material was paced and divided well. I would have liked more information on applying the topics to practical engineering situations.

There's a lot of assistance available if you need it-- office hours three times a week, study halls twice per week. I liked the flipped classroom, but it's not for everyone. 

The biggest weakness is that the tests were unnecessarily difficult.
The strength is in the feedback on midterms and example problems. The weakness is the variance in types of lectures.

Its a good class. PROFESSOR VIDVUDS OZOLINS IS AMAZING. I highly recommend him. He will be patient with you and is dedicated to helping student learn!

I really learned the most when we had the kahoots during class. Please bring those back. I learned so much better and I was very engaged in class.

I thought that the class was overall pretty strong. It is nice to be taught the math, with consideration for what we will be doing with it later. I also thought doing Kahoot! In class made it much more interesting and made it easier to remain engaged, as when we were just doing problems on the board it was easy to lose concentration
The course is great, but perhaps adding more examples of "application" in the class would improve the overall quality of the class

This is difficult material and a lot to cram into one semester, but this class was well structured and the problem sets were very effective at helping me learn to actually use what we learned in class. Kahoot was definitely a strength of this class.
Lectures were not helpful, exams were very difficult. A nice curve in the end but overall a stressful class

I thought the material was interesting, but I wish that going over problems in class had been more solving problems together rather than having the answers written up on the board. I felt like solutions were often given in place of methodology.
Professor Ozolins was very good at keeping the lectures interesting. I enjoyed coming to class even when I didn't understand all of the material.

The course format was a little tough to keep up with; we were expected to have essentially taught ourselves beforehand, and then were treated to a slideshow that reviewed the content at breakneck speed.  Later on, we switched to doing problems in class, but these were always far easier than what we might be expected to complete on an exam.  We came closer to hitting our stride towards the end, when we would focus on doing a few hard problems our on the board instead of flying through some slides.  In the end, I feel like most of the learning I had was form the textbook, with classes serving to solidify some concepts.

This course could be improved if the professor attempted to teach as if he were first learning the math all over again. He jumped way too fast over things and didn't explicitly describe how to do things.

Strengths: The course was very lenient with grading (main focus was to learn the content)

Weaknesses: We changed our lecture style three different times, which was annoying to keep up with. Additionally, I think the professor focused too much on the theory and not the actual way we should solve problems.
Very good professor with a willingness to help students. A little too much learning from the book with not much explanation in class.

The biggest problem with this course was it's supposedly "flipped classroom setup," though other flipped classes I've taken -- such as Math 115--have video lectures that are supposed to teach you the material before class. The idea with this class, however, was that you would just read the book before class and just KNOW everything from that. This was then used as an excuse to rush through material in class, instead of explaining things at a level that could be understood by those who don't already know the material, even though reading the book before class is just a normal expectation of any class, and any good teacher would still teach that material during class.
The professor is very open to adjusting the class and lecture style to best suite the needs and preferences of the students.

Good course for people who have taken multivariable calculus before. For those who haven't, you'll really have to work at it. I like how we are given physical interpretation for the mathematical concepts we learn. This really sets this course apart from Math 120.

It covers a large amount of material throughout multivariable calc. I liked that even though the class was larger than the average 120 class, it had fewer students in total which made it kind of less stressful. I think a weakness is that the class has to move so fast that the material is not covered in depth during class, so a lot of work outside of class is required if you don't get the concepts right away.

Throughout the first 23 or so lectures, the professors preferred method of teaching included PowerPoint, and in-class Kahoot for a few of the last lectures. In my opinion this is a core weakness of the course, simply because the pace of the course is only accelerated by presentations of the already difficult subject. Many times I found myself confused and even lost during lecture because the information was being presented at such a fast pace that I did not have enough time to process what the professor was saying, even after having read the necessary sections in the book the night before. I believe that most mathematics, especially a subject as hard as multivariable calculus, should be taught in a traditional manner, with the professor writing on a board and explaining the topic to the class as he goes along. Simply projecting the images and example problems from the textbook onto a screen and calling it a lecture is a very ineffective method of instruction; in order for students to perform well in the class, they should be given multiple viewpoints on the same topic to maximize understanding. Kahoot practice problems in class, although engaging, did very little in enhancing my understanding of the material. Often times the timer on the screen placed a great deal of pressure on the students to guess and submit an answer for the sake of getting a chance to garner some points and rise on the leaderboard. Lecture shouldnt be made to feel like a competition, regardless of intent. 

Strengths of this class include the comfortable setting and opportunities to seek extra help during office hours.

The class was very much the professor reading off of slides that took straight of the text book and little explanation about the topics outside of the book. in class he read off of slides for an hour then we watched him do problems for the second half of class where he would explain every question using words as "obviously" and "easily" not catering to students who have not already seen this material before. Only after the first half of the semester did he start using interactive problems that were very trivial and helped little with the PSETs and tests. There were little resources and the TAs often were not helpful for the problem sets. The solutions for extra problems were rarely posted and if they were posted at all they were not in a timely manner. This class needs to do more that just repeat everything we already read in the book and explain things we read further especially if there were any confusions (which there often was).

The weakness of this course is that some first year students have already taken this course before, and some students haven't. Therefore, there are many differences, people that can follow the class better, and  some other people that struggle more.

I really enjoyed this course. I liked the order in which topics were presented, and the abundance of challenging practice problems. I would have liked slightly more time spent on the underlying conceptseven "engineers and physicists" can sometimes enjoy mathbut that's a personal preference.

I found this course to be very confusing in terms of what to expect. The material itself wouldn't be terrible if it had a decent teacher, which I hear is hit or miss. The tests seemed to be of a whole other level relative to the rest of the class.

Sometimes a few of the integral types got a little muddled together in my mind. It would have been nice to see some sort of interactive or applied component, even at the expense of covering some material.

Yes. Professor Ozolins is amazing in many ways:
1) humor
2) changing his teaching style on a dime to fit the desires of students
3) extremely well organized
4) he is really smart
Solid math class. Excellent especially for engineers because the math is very much application based.
Yes!

No, I would not recommend this class. The only people that excelled in this class were people that took multivariable before and were already very familiar with the topics. The class is very challenging for people with no experience with multivariable calculus. Take this class with a different professor.
I would only recommend this class to someone if they have already taken multivariable calc because that is possibly the only way you will be able to keep up.

Yes, it's better than 120 because it forces you to put in the work to do the reading and do well on the psets because they really impact your grade. This class is still challenging even if you already took multivariable in high school because you have to fully understand the concepts to do well on the exam.

I would recommend this class to a student who already has a solid foundation in multi variable calculus and who wants to further fine tune their calculus skills. But if you have never taken multi variable calculus before, I would not recommend this class because it is taught much too quickly with insufficient in class explanation of the course material.

I would recommend this course only to students not planning to pursue math past this class: MATH 120 will definitely prepare you more for linear algebra and beyond. However, try and get the previous teacher (the one before Vidvuds Ozolins), since Ozolins is not the best teacher for this class (see the other comments).
I would certainly recommend the course to fellow engineering students.

I recommend it as an alternative to Math 120 if you're willing to put in the work. If you're considering majoring in physics or math, it's probably more useful than Math 230. Just be aware that (at least with Professor Ozolins) the exams are hard.

I would not recommend this course to another student unless he or she needs it for a major requirement. It is a class of many students and only one professor, giving little to no individual attention or extra help.

Yes

If you're doing engineering take this over Math 120.
I thought overall the class was good. The subject material was taught pretty well, and the professor was engaging and fun.
This is a class you take because your major says you have to. That said, it was well taught and better paced than math 120.
I would recommend the course to someone who is prepared to learn the material on their own, but is not interesting in the mathematical proofs that pertain to multi-variable calculus.
Yes. Choose this instead of Math 120.
I would recommend this to another student who was somewhat familiar with the concepts of multivariable calculus already. I would not recommend it to someone who had no prior experience with multi.

While I've heard good things about ENAS 151, this semester seemed pretty convoluted to me.  I think I'd definitely make sure that any non-engineer prospective students check out math 120 or an equivalent.  That's not to say that ENAS should be out of the question, but I also don't think I'd specifically recommend it.
No I would recommend math 120 because of the different teaching styles by other professors.
Yes, b/c it's better than Math 120; the grading is easier. Otherwise I wouldn't recommend it unless one is good at Calc 2.
Yes, from what I heard from friends, it is the better alternative to Math 120

If Vidvuds Ozolins is teaching this class again, I would not recommend it unless you're one of those kids who has already taken multi in high school. I would STRONGLY recommend taking Math 120 instead. You do very few applications to engineering problems, the workload is greater, the curve is worse, the psets are longer, and there are fewer TAs. I was tempted because more of your grade comes from psets than in math 120, but the psets are so impossible that this doesn't even help anyways. The class is taught absolutely awfully: its supposedly structured as "flipped classroom," but all that meant was you were supposed to read the book before class - which is pretty reasonable for any class - but the UNREASONABLE part is this was then used as an excuse to merely quickly glance over material in class with little to no explanation, followed by a lots of examples that really only involved writing down the problem giving the class a minute, and then writing down the answer. Most of the semester was taught either through powerpoint of math or endless Kahoot problems that only the same 7 people who took multi in high school get right. I hated this class, There were several occasions where I asked questions in class because I didn't understand something, and he would simply say something like "Isn't it obvious?" and continue. I left this class literally crying on multiple occasions, and it was by far the hardest class I have taken at Yale, and no, I'm not a freshman. Save yourself the pain and take math 120, this class just isn't worth it.
I would recommend this class, as I learned a lot, enjoyed all of the lectures, and had lots of available help.

Recommend. Great course for people who have taken multi before and want to go into more depth. If you haven't taken multi before, expect to read and do the pre-lectures to understand the concepts. Psets are a fun challenge and make you think. However, if you've taken multi before, expect to learn some but not a whole lot from this course.

Yes, as long as that student is prepared to do a lot of work outside of the class to strengthen their understanding. I liked the more personal feel than I think that you would get with 120, just because their are fewer students in total. Like I said though, I think that this class, if you don't have any prior knowledge of multivariable calc, this class can be really tough to grasp, so it will require a lot of additional work to grasp concepts and get a solid understanding. The lectures move fast because they have to cover a lot of material, so if you don't do anything outside of class a lot of the lecture material will fly past.

I would recommend this course for students who seek a larger lecture class than those offered in Math 120 for the chance to form study groups with more people. Aside from that, I would not recommend this course as an alternative to Math 120. My suite mates who were enrolled in Math 120 seemingly were not as stressed about multivariable calculus than I was although they agreed that it was a difficult subject. To my surprise I never learned the difference between ENAS 151 and Math 120 aside from the titles of the courses. The problem sets in ENAS 151 took on average (at least for me and a few friends) anywhere between 10-14 hours of pure work to complete, whereas my friends enrolled in Math 120 never complained about the amount of time it took for them to complete their weekly problem sets.

I would not recommend this class to someone who has not already had some background knowledge in multivariable calculus. This class is different with every professor however. The main perk of this class is that for every test we get to create out own formula sheet which you do not get to do for Math 120.
If they are interested in pursuing an engineering career, I would recommend this course. It helps have a better understanding, but it is also a very challenging class.

I would wholeheartedly recommend this course to anyone who isn't planning to major in math. From conversations with friends in MAT120 I can see that I've been left with essentially the same knowledge of concepts, with perhaps a slightly greater degree of practice in applications, after a much less stressful semester.
I would not recommend this class. My friends in Math 120 seemed to all have a better time than anyone I knew in ENAS 151.

Yes. You do have to engage, though, if you want to get that A. The math is tough and if you need help with it, you have to seek it. However, perhaps just by the strength of the instructor and judging from my peers' assessments, I'd strongly recommend this over Math 120.
